rdfs:comment: Changes in this version: - discontinued use of owl:sameAs fordifferent descriptions of the same person. These are now listed as a single instance, with multiple name_en values, and a single rdfs:label which is (sort of) canonical. -minor corrections
Maintenance note: the underlying ontology (NTNames.owl) is still under development, so it's important the owl:imports statement stays up-to-date -- Sean 2005-02-13

The names here are as
transliterated in the English Standard Version (ESV), copyright Â©
2001 by Crossway Bibles, a division of Good News Publishers.

Reuse note: where feasible, class names coincide with SUMO (Suggested
Upper Merged Ontology), as developed within the IEEE Standard Upper
Ontology Working Group, described at http://www.ontologyportal.org/,
and available as OWL at http://reliant.teknowledge.com/DAML/SUMO.owl
(But Not Without Some Problems). I've copied, rather than re-used, but
this provides a future migration path toward coordinating the two
ontologies.

Location data taken from http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showthreaded.php/Cat/0/Number/517264.

@graph.nt:description: Moses' assistant during the Exodus
@graph.rdfs:label: Aaron

@graph.nt:description: High priest during the lifetime of King David
@graph.rdfs:label: Abiathar

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: His occupation as king comes from Old Testament sources, 2Chr.12-13.
@graph.rdfs:label: Abijah

@graph.nt:description: A priest appointed by King David
@graph.rdfs:comment: Zacharias, father of John the Baptist, was a descendant of Abijah.
@graph.rdfs:label: Abijah

@graph.nt:description: The founder of the Hebrew nation.
rdfs:label: Abraham
Abram

@graph.nt:description: A member of Corinthian church who visited the Apostle Paul in Ephesus, perhaps bearing a letter to him.
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His residence in Corinth and visit to Ephesus follow from Paul's statement in 1Cor.16.17, and the assumption that Paul was in Ephesus when he wrote 1 Corinthians.
@graph.rdfs:label: Achaicus

@graph.nt:description: The first created human
@graph.rdfs:comment: Though Luke's geneaology lists Adam as "the son of God", this is not in the biological sense of childOf
@graph.rdfs:label: Adam

@graph.nt:description: A paralytic healed by Peter
@graph.rdfs:label: Aeneas

@graph.nt:description: A prophet in the Jerusalem church who visited Antioch and foretold of a coming famine.
@graph.rdfs:label: Agabus

nt:description.@value: King of Judah during the time of Isaiah

@graph.rdfs:comment: See OT descriptions in 2 Kings 16; Isa. 7-9; 2 Chr. 28.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ahaz

nt:description.@value: Probably an early Christian known to Mark, who mentions him as the son of Simon of Cyrene, who was compelled to carry Jesus' cross

@graph.nt:description: A Jew in Ephesus who was put forward to quiet the crowd during the riot caused by Demetrius
@graph.rdfs:label: Alexander

@graph.nt:description: A relative of Annas the High Priest who was present when Peter and John were questioned about healing a lame man
@graph.rdfs:label: Alexander

@graph.nt:description: A resident of Ephesus who caused Paul "great harm"
@graph.rdfs:comment: This may be the same as AlexanderTheHeretic, since they are both identified as opponents of Paul and the Gospel, and they both resided in Ephesus.
@graph.rdfs:label: Alexander

@graph.nt:description: Described to Timothy by Paul as having "rejected conscience"
@graph.rdfs:label: Alexander

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: "Eli" is Aramaic for "My God".
@graph.rdfs:label: Almighty

nt:description.@value: The father of James, one of the Twelve

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: The identification of Alphaeus with Clopas is not completely certain: see ISBE for Alphaeus.
@graph.rdfs:label: Alphaeus

@graph.nt:description: The father of Levi, one of the Twelve
@graph.rdfs:comment: That both James the Less and Levi had fathers named Alphaeus has led some to speculate they were brothers, but this seems unlikely.
@graph.rdfs:label: Alphaeus

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:comment: There's no evidence other than the similar (and not uncommon) name to suggest this man is the same Amos as the Old Testament prophet.
@graph.rdfs:label: Amos

@graph.nt:description: A member of the early church in Jerusalem who conspired with his wife to deceive the church about a gift of property, and who was consequently struck dead.
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Residence in Jerusalem is assumed by the account in Acts 5, where the church is still primarily Jersualem-based.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ananias

@graph.nt:description: Ananias was sent to Paul to restore his sight, after his encounter with Christ on the road to Damascus
@graph.rdfs:label: Ananias

@graph.nt:description: Jewish High Priest during the time of the Apostle Paul
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: ISBE describes him as a Sadducee, though it's not clear why.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ananias

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles, and the first one called.
@graph.rdfs:comment: One could infer that Andrew followed Jesus back from Bethany to Galilee in his early ministry, and therefore visited Cana and Capernaum. But this is not explicitly described.
@graph.rdfs:label: Andrew

nt:description.@value: A Christian in Rome to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.rdfs:comment: Paul's description of Andronicus as "my kinsman" is taken in the general snese (e.g. coming from the same region), rather than literally. As a "fellow-prisoner", he and Junia are assumed to be collaborators with Paul.
@graph.rdfs:label: Andronicus

@graph.nt:description: a prophetess who spoke about the infant Jesus in the temple
@graph.rdfs:label: Anna

@graph.nt:description: Jewish high-priest (prior to Jesus' ministry)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Annas' highpriesthood ended in 15 AD, but he continued to be described as high-priest after his son-in-law, Caiaphas, had taken the position.
@graph.rdfs:label: Annas

@graph.rdfs:comment: This Antioch is located in the Pisidian region of Asia Minor, a different place from the town of the same name in Syria
rdfs:label: Antioch
Antioch in Pisidia

@graph.nt:description: a martyr
@graph.rdfs:label: Antipas

nt:description.@value: a Christian in Rome whom Paul greeted

@graph.nt:description: an eloquent evangelist whose ministry was initially based only on the teachings of John the Baptist
@graph.rdfs:label: Apollos

@graph.rdfs:comment:
Being the spouseOf Philemon is implied by their mention together in the salutation of the Letter to Philemon, though it is not definite. 
Paul describes her as "our sister", presumably in Christ rather than literally. See Philemon about ResidentPlace.
@graph.rdfs:label: Apphia

@graph.nt:description: a tentmaked converted by Paul who, together with his wife, became evangelists
@graph.rdfs:label: Aquila

@graph.nt:description: one of the sons of Herod the Great who ruled Judea for a time
@graph.rdfs:label: Archelaus

@graph.nt:description: a Christian in Colossae whom Paul describes as "our fellow soldier"
@graph.rdfs:comment: Paul describes Archippus as "our fellow soldier" in Philemon 1:2, perhaps based on service together in Ephesus (RWP).
@graph.rdfs:label: Archippus

@graph.nt:description: a king in Paul's time whose rule included Damascus
@graph.rdfs:label: Aretas

@graph.rdfs:comment: Arimathea is known as the native place of Joseph, a member of the Sanhedrin and a disciple who put Jesus' body in his own tomb after the crucifixion.
@graph.rdfs:label: Arimathea

nt:description.@value: a traveling companion of Paul

@graph.nt:description: an inhabitant of Rome
@graph.rdfs:comment: Paul addresses "the family/household of Aristobulus", which may refer to slaves: so we have no evidence about the beliefs or other attributes of Aristobulus himself, other than his residence in Rome. One of the grandsons of Herod the Great had this name, though the name was common enough that this need not be the same man.
@graph.rdfs:label: Aristobulus

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Likely a variant form of Ram, as Hezron's son is called in Matthew's genealogy.
@graph.rdfs:label: Arni

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Arphaxad

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not the same as the psalmist and leader of King David's choir in 1Chr.6.39.
@graph.rdfs:label: Asaph

@graph.nt:description: One of the 12 Patriarchs of Israel
@graph.rdfs:comment: One of the sons of Judah
@graph.rdfs:label: Asher

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.rdfs:comment: A Roman legion.
@graph.rdfs:label: Augustan Cohort

@graph.nt:description: Emperor of Rome at the time of Jesus' birth
@graph.rdfs:label: Augustus

@graph.rdfs:comment: Babylon also has a metaphorical usage as a symbol of the world system opposed to God
@graph.rdfs:label: Babylon

@graph.nt:description: an Old Testament figure and negative example
@graph.rdfs:label: Balaam

@graph.nt:description: king of Moab who hired Balaam
@graph.rdfs:label: Balak

@graph.nt:description: a magician and false prophet who Paul and Silas encountered on Cyprus
@graph.rdfs:comment: Elymas is a transliteration of an Aramaic or Arabic word equivalent to 'magician'.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bar-Jesus

@graph.nt:description: a criminal, released in place of Jesus
@graph.rdfs:label: Barabbas

@graph.nt:description: an Old Testament military leader from the book of Judges
@graph.rdfs:label: Barak

@graph.nt:description: a close companion of the Apostle Paul
@graph.rdfs:label: Barnabas

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:comment: Many believe Bartholemew is another name for Nathanael, though their identity is deduced rather than stated.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bartholomew

@graph.nt:description: a blind beggar whom Jesus healed
@graph.rdfs:label: Bartimaeus

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not named in the New Testament, but referred to in Matt.1.6 as "the wife of Uriah". Since Uriah was a Hittite, it's not clear what her religiousBelief might have been.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bathsheba

@graph.nt:description: One of the 12 Patriarchs of Israel
@graph.rdfs:label: Benjamin

nt:description.@value: a daughter of Herod Agrippa I who heard Paul's defense to her brother, Herod Agrippa II

@graph.rdfs:comment: Smith notes that Bernice "lived  under circumstances of great suspicion" with her brother Herod Agrippa II, i.e. they may have had an incestuous relationship.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bernice

@graph.rdfs:comment: Distinguished from the Bethany near Jerusalem: since the time of Origen, the location has been unknown.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bethany beyond the Jordan
geodata for Bethany Beyond the Jordan

@graph.rdfs:comment:
NNE of Sea of Galilee, "Bethsaida Julia". ISBE has a thorough account
of whether, given Mark 6.45 and John's "Bethsaida of Galilee", 
there were two such towns (with a second, smaller one on the west side),
or only one
@graph.rdfs:label: Bethsaida

@graph.nt:description: the chamberlain of Herod Agrippa
@graph.rdfs:label: Blastus

@graph.rdfs:comment: Jesus' nickname for two of his disciples: James, the son of Zebedee, and John, his brother.
rdfs:label: Boanerges
Sons of Thunder

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: Roman Emperor at the time of Jesus' birth
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Caesar is used as a name for several different individuals in the New Testament
@graph.rdfs:label: Caesar

@graph.nt:description: Roman Emperor during Paul's ministry
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Caesar is used as a name for several different individuals in the New Testament
@graph.rdfs:label: Caesar

@graph.nt:description: Jewish high priest during Jesus' ministry
@graph.rdfs:label: Caiaphas

@graph.nt:description: the first son of Adam and Eve, who killed his brother Abel
@graph.rdfs:label: Cain

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Cainan

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:comment: Kenan in the NIV
@graph.rdfs:label: Cainan

@graph.rdfs:comment: see Caiaphas
@graph.rdfs:label: Caiphas

@graph.rdfs:comment: In the Old Testament, a people living west of the Jordan river who were partially displaced by the Israelites. In New Testament times, Canaanites lived primarily in the area of Phoenicia. Cananean, in contrast, is almost certainly political, rather than ethnic.
@graph.rdfs:label: Canaanite

@graph.rdfs:comment: This attribute is only used by Matthew and Mark to describe Simon, one of Jesus' disciples. Given what else we know of Simon, it almost certainly designates a political attribute, rather than ethnicity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Cananaean

@graph.rdfs:comment: Candace is actually a title like "Pharaoh" rather than a personal name, hence her occupation as queen.
@graph.rdfs:label: Candace

@graph.nt:description: an associate of Paul's, whom the Apostle entrusted with books, parchments, and his cloak
@graph.rdfs:label: Carpus

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: "Chloe's people" are mentioned in 1Cor.1.11: so while they were clearly Christians who knew the church in Corinth, nothing more specific is known about her. She may have resided in Ephesus instead of Corinth.
@graph.rdfs:label: Chloe

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not referenced as a belief system in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Christianity

@graph.nt:description: Household manager of Herod Antipas
@graph.rdfs:comment: Though Chuza's wife was a devoted follower of Jesus, there's no evidence as to Chuza's belief.
@graph.rdfs:label: Chuza

nt:description.@value: a Christian who sent greeetings to Timothy in Paul's second epislte.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Rome as ResidentPlace because Paul was imprisoned there when writing to Timothy.
@graph.rdfs:label: Claudia

@graph.nt:description: One of the emperors of Rome
@graph.rdfs:label: Claudius

nt:description.@value: the military tribune commanding the Roman forces in Jerusalem

@graph.rdfs:comment: Greek ethnicity is suggested by his surname.
@graph.rdfs:label: Claudius Lysias

@graph.nt:description: a companion of the Apostle Paul
@graph.rdfs:label: Clement

@graph.nt:description: one of the two travellers on the road to Emmaus to whom Jesus appeared after his resurrection
@graph.rdfs:comment: "The name is a contraction of Cleopatros, not identical with Clopas of Joh 19:25." (ISBE) Jerusalem could have been his place of residence.
@graph.rdfs:label: Cleopas
@graph.owl:versionInfo: TODO: Cleopas knew the 11, and the women who went to the tomb

@graph.nt:description: a companion of the Apostle Paul
@graph.rdfs:comment: Crescens may have been from Rome originally
@graph.rdfs:label: Crescens

@graph.nt:description: a Corinthian Christian, and former ruler of the synagogue there
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: As a prominent member of the church at Corinth, it seems reasonable to assume Crispus would know the other people from Corinth mentioned in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Crispus

nt:description.@value: a convert from Paul's address to the Aeropagus

@graph.rdfs:comment: Damaris was converted through Paul's preaching in Athens.
@graph.rdfs:label: Damaris

@graph.nt:description: an Old Testament prophet
@graph.rdfs:label: Daniel

@graph.nt:description: Israel's greatest king; author of many of the Old Testament Psalms
@graph.rdfs:label: David

@graph.rdfs:comment: Though Paul describes Demas as "my fellow worker" in Philemon, later he apparently deserted him and went to Thessalonica. He was with Paul when he wrote his letter to  Philemon and the Colossians, but Paul's location when writing them is uncertain.
@graph.rdfs:label: Demas

nt:description.@value: a disciple mentioned in 3 John as having a good reputation

@graph.rdfs:comment: See comment on DemetriusTheSilversmith. Keener suggests that 3John is a letter of support which Demetrius carried to Gaius.
@graph.rdfs:label: Demetrius

nt:description.@value: a craftsman in Ephesus who made silver shrines of Artemis

@graph.rdfs:comment: Demetrius was a common name, so it's unlikely this man is the same as the disciple mentioned in 3John.1.12.
@graph.rdfs:label: Demetrius

@graph.rdfs:comment: Though nothing else is recorded about Dionysius, the exclusivity and prestige of the Areopagus makes his descriptive surname significant.
@graph.rdfs:label: Dionysius

nt:description.@value: a member of the church to which 3 John was addressed
wife of Felix

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Drusilla's locations are inferred from those of her husband. According to Josephus, she was the daughter of Herod Agrippa I.
@graph.rdfs:label: Drusilla

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Eber

@graph.rdfs:comment: Only used in the New Testament to refer to those whose place of birth is Egypt.
@graph.rdfs:label: Egyptian

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Eliakim

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Eliakim

@graph.nt:description: one of the most notable prophets in the Old Testament
@graph.rdfs:comment: John the Baptist represented Elijah returned to his contemporaries, and the name is sometimes therefore used to refer to John (e.g. Matt.17.12).
@graph.rdfs:label: Elijah

nt:description.@value: an Old Testament prophet
One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
the mother of John the Baptist

@graph.rdfs:comment: Elizabeth was a kinswoman to Mary the mother of Jesus. Luke's gospel records that Mary visited her in a town in Judah, and that she was "of the daughters of Aaron".
@graph.rdfs:label: Elizabeth

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Emmaus is a village about seven miles from Jerusalem. Jesus joined two disciples who were walking here, though they did not recognize Him until the end of the journey.
@graph.rdfs:label: Emmaus

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Different from the eldest son of Cain (Gen.4:17)
@graph.rdfs:label: Enoch

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Enosh in the NIV
@graph.rdfs:label: Enos

nt:description.@value: A Christian in Rome whom Paul describes as "the first convert to Christ in Asia"
A fellow minister with Paul, and likely founder of the Colossian church

@graph.rdfs:comment: Paul mentions that Epaphras "worked hard" for those in Laodicea and Hierapolis, so it's possible (but not certain) he visited there as well.
@graph.rdfs:label: Epaphras

nt:description.@value: A Christian sent by the Philippian church with a gift for Paul

@graph.rdfs:comment:
Though Epaphras is a contraction of Epaphroditus, this individual is distinct from the Epaphras mentioned in Colossians and Philemon.
Rome as a visitedPlace assumes Paul was there while writing Philippians.
@graph.rdfs:label: Epaphroditus

@graph.rdfs:comment: Jesus retreated to this town with his disciples when the Jews plotted to kill him after Lazarus was raised from the dead.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ephraim

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
a travelling companion of Paul

@graph.rdfs:comment: There are two references to this Erastus: it's possible they represent two different people. See also the comment on ErastusTheTreasurer.
@graph.rdfs:label: Erastus

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: It is uncertain whether this Erastus is the same as Paul's travelling companion and fellow minister, though possible.

nt:description.@value: a character from the Old Testament era

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Esli

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not named in the New Testament.
Of the country of Ethiopia.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ethiopian

@graph.nt:description: a Christian companion of the Apostle Paul in his Roman imprisonment
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His residence in Rome assumes
@graph.rdfs:label: Eubulus

@graph.nt:description: the mother of Timothy
@graph.rdfs:comment: Eunice's residence in Lystra is implied by Acts.16.1, though Derbe is also possible. Her Christian faith is strongly implied by Paul's commendation of it in 2Tim.1.5.
@graph.rdfs:label: Eunice

@graph.nt:description: a Christian in Philippi
@graph.rdfs:label: Euodia

@graph.nt:description: a young man who fell asleep during a lengthy sermon by Paul
@graph.rdfs:label: Eutychus

@graph.nt:description: the first woman created by God
@graph.rdfs:label: Eve

@graph.nt:description: governor of Judea during the time when Paul was arrested in the Temple
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Properly Antonius Felix
@graph.rdfs:label: Felix

@graph.nt:description: governor of Judea after Felix
@graph.rdfs:label: Festus

@graph.nt:description: A member of Corinthian church who visited the Apostle Paul in Ephesus, perhaps bearing a letter to him.
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His residence in Corinth and visit to Ephesus follow from Paul's statement in 1Cor.16.17, and the assumption that Paul was in Ephesus when he wrote 1 Corinthians.
@graph.rdfs:label: Fortunatus

nt:description.@value: One of the 12 Patriarchs of Israel

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His mother Zilpah, Leah's servant, is not named in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gad

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com:
City southeast of the Sea of Galilee. Not mentioned in Scripture as such, but "the country of the Gadarenes" (Matt 8.28) takes its name from this city. 
Part of the Decapolis.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gadara

@graph.nt:description: one whom Paul baptized in Corinth
@graph.rdfs:comment: Since Paul's Epistle to the Romans was written from Corinth, this is assumed to be the one Paul describes as "host to me and the whole church"
@graph.rdfs:label: Gaius

@graph.nt:description: a travelling companion of Paul's
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Luke describes him as "Gaius of Derbe": that could be either his place of birth, or place of residence. It's not clear whether he (and his other companions) accompanied Paul all the way to Jerusalem. Gaius being a common name, it seems plausible that the others of the same name are distinct individuals, though the closest possible identification is with GaiusOfMacedonia (see New Bible Dictionary for discussion).
@graph.rdfs:label: Gaius

@graph.nt:description: a traveling companion of Paul's
@graph.rdfs:comment: It seems likely this Gaius was a Christian since he was Paul's "companion in travel", though this is not explicitly stated.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gaius

@graph.nt:description: "the beloved" to whom John addresses his third epistle
@graph.rdfs:label: Gaius

@graph.rdfs:comment: In the time of Christ, Galilee was home to those of Jewish descent as well non-Jews. As used in the New Testament, the term is used primarily of Jews in distinction to Judean and Samaritan, the other major divisions of Jewish Palestine. It is therefore (in practice) a sub-ethnicity of Jewish.
@graph.rdfs:label: Galilean

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: He is not considered an antagonist of Paul because his only involvement was indifference.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gallio

nt:description.@value: a respected Jewish teacher whom Paul studied under

@graph.rdfs:comment: An area on the west side of the Sea of Galilee, where Jesus healed the sick
@graph.rdfs:label: Gennesaret

@graph.rdfs:comment: Essentially a "non-ethnicity" meaning not Jewish.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gentile

nt:description.@value: a  judge of Israel prior to the monarchy
an apocalyptic opponent of God's people

@graph.rdfs:comment: The historic background of the reference to Gog is most likely the Lydian king in the 7th Century BC. Its usage in Revelation seems to describe a group of people,  but it is hard to be certain what is intended in this apocalyptic context.
@graph.rdfs:label: Gog

@graph.rdfs:comment: Sometimes used synomymously with Gentile, but certainly means non-Jewish in ethnicity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Greek

@graph.rdfs:comment: The state or place of the dead. SUO restricts use of GeographicArea to places on the earth.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hades

nt:description.@value: mother of Ishmael; servant to Abraham's wife Sarah

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: her son Ishmael is not named in the New Testament
@graph.rdfs:label: Hagar

@graph.rdfs:comment: In his speech before the Council, Stephen refers to Haran as a place where Abraham lived.
@graph.rdfs:label: Haran

@graph.rdfs:comment: See the comment on Joseph for why Heli is listed as parentOf Mary, not Joseph, despite Luke 3:23.
@graph.rdfs:label: Heli

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings
a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings
a Christian who refused to help Paul during his Roman imprisonment

@graph.rdfs:comment: The circumstances behind his "turning away" from Paul are unknown. Likewise, Paul's description of him as being "is Asia" isn't specific enough to assign a place.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hermogenes

@graph.nt:description: King of Chalcis from AD 50-92: the last member of the Herodian dynasty
@graph.rdfs:label: Herod Agrippa II

@graph.nt:description: ruler of Judea during Jesus' adult life
@graph.rdfs:comment: Herod the Great was Idumean, and Antipas' mother was Samaritan. According to extra-biblical history, he was educated in Rome.
rdfs:label: Herod the tetrarch
Herod

@graph.nt:description: King of Judea at the time of Jesus' birth
@graph.rdfs:label: Herod

nt:description.@value: wife of Herod Antipas who had John the Baptist put to death

@graph.rdfs:comment: Herodias had John the Baptist put to death
@graph.rdfs:label: Herodias

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Paul's description of Herodian as "my kinsman" is taken in the general snese (e.g. coming from the same region), rather than literally.
@graph.rdfs:label: Herodion

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: This name designates the nation inhabited by the descendants of Jacob's twelve sons. For Israel the patriarch, see Jacob. For the inhabitants of this nation, see Israelites.
@graph.rdfs:label: Israel

@graph.rdfs:comment: A Roman legion
@graph.rdfs:label: Italian Cohort

@graph.rdfs:comment: An area to the NW of the Sea of Galilee. It's unclear whether this refers to a definite region or an undefined general area occupied by the Ituraeans, a migratory tribe.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ituraea

nt:description.@value: The patriarch of the nation of Israel, son of Isaac and Abraham

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Israel becomes a metonym describing the nation of descendants from Jacob, so it is used both for a individual, a nation, and the members of that nation.
rdfs:label: Jacob
Israel

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: Grandfather of Joseph, the husband of Mary, the mother of Jesus
@graph.rdfs:label: Jacob

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:label: James

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Jannai

nt:description.@value: a companion of Paul's who sent greetings to the Roman church

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His residence in Corinth follows from the inference that Paul resided there when he wrote the letter to the Roman church.  "kinsman" here probably means that that he is a Jew, rather than an actual relative, given the number of people so designated in Romans 16.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jason

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
the father of King David

@graph.nt:description: Jesus Christ, the Messiah and Son of God
@graph.rdfs:comment: As the central figure of the New Testament, it is impossible to incorporate all the information about Jesus in this limited framework.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jesus

@graph.rdfs:comment: The notion of 'Jewish' as an ethnicity is problematic given the long history of God's chosen people and their many circumstances. Here it refers broadly to the Jewish identity, and is applied to all those from Abraham through Peter and Paul who would designate themselves as Jewish. In particular, no attempt is made to distinguish pre-Mosaic Jewish ethnicity from later forms. Israelite is only used a few times in the New Testament, and in those instances, it is treated synonymously with Jewish.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jewish

nt:description.@value: the pagan wife of Ahab in the Old Testament

@graph.rdfs:comment: This may be a figurative reference based on the pagan wife of Ahab in the Old Testament, rather than the actual name of a contemporary person.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jezebel

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Joanan

nt:description.@value: a woman wno contributed to Jesus' support

@graph.rdfs:comment: Probably of Jewish ethnicity
@graph.rdfs:label: Joanna

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Joda

@graph.rdfs:comment: One of Paul's companions
@graph.rdfs:label: John Mark

@graph.nt:description: A relative of Annas the High Priest who was present when Peter and John were questioned about healing a lame man
@graph.rdfs:label: John

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:label: John

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com:
John certainly understood Jesus to be the Messiah and was a person of faith, but he cannot be accounted a Christian since Jesus' ministry was not yet accomplished when he was beheaded. 
The use of the name Elijah to refer to John the Baptist is figurative.
rdfs:label: John the Baptist
John

@graph.nt:description: Father of Peter and Andrew, two of Jesus' 12 disciples
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Bethsaide is assumed as his place of residence because his sons were from there. He was probably a fisherman, though nothing else is said of him in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jonah

@graph.nt:description: A prophet from the Old Testmanent
@graph.rdfs:label: Jonah

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Jonam

@graph.rdfs:comment: In Joppa, Peter raised the woman Tabitha from the dead. Later, he had a vision while praying there that prepared him for the coming of the Holy Spirit to the first Gentiles.
@graph.rdfs:label: Joppa

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His occupation as King comes from Old Testament sources.
@graph.rdfs:label: Joram

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Josech

nt:description.@value: the earthly father of Jesus

@graph.rdfs:comment:
Joseph was Jesus' parent in the normal sense, even though not his biological father.
Luke 3:23 has "Joseph, son of Heli", though Matthew has Joseph's father named Jacob. Here I've represented the opinion that Joseph was actually son-in-law of Heli, and that Luke's geneaology describes Mary's lineage rather than Joseph's.
@graph.rdfs:label: Joseph

@graph.nt:description: an early Christian who was put forward (but not chosen) as a replacement for Judas Iscariot
@graph.rdfs:label: Joseph Barsabbas

@graph.rdfs:comment: Joseph was a member of the Jewish ruling council, and a follower of Jesus. He put Jesus' body in his own tomb after the crucifixion. {en}
@graph.rdfs:label: Joseph of Arimathea

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Joseph

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Joseph

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Joshua

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His occupation as King comes from Old Testament sources, 2Chron.26-27.
@graph.rdfs:label: Jotham

@graph.nt:description: One of the 12 Patriarchs of Israel, after whom the land of Judea took its name.
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Tamar was not actually his spouse, but his daughter-in-law (Gen 38).
@graph.rdfs:label: Judah

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Judah

@graph.rdfs:comment: This is distinct from Jewish as an ethnic heritage, which implies birth: one can have a ReligiousBelief of Judaism through conversion, despite not having Jewish ethnicity. Those who convert to other beliefs (most notably for the New Testament, Christianity) are typically designated as having Jewish ethnicity, but Christianity as a ReligiousBelief. There is no implication of faithful devotion to the Jewish faith.
@graph.rdfs:label: Judaism

@graph.nt:description: a prophet in the church at Antioch
@graph.rdfs:label: Judas

@graph.rdfs:comment: The main subgroup of Jewish Palestine at the time of Christ: to be Judean therefore implies being Jewish as well. This is distinct from describing those of the tribe and lineage of Judah.
@graph.rdfs:label: Judean

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Julia may be the spouse or sister of Philologus, given their mention together in Rom.16.15
@graph.rdfs:label: Julia

nt:description.@value: a "kinsman" and fellow prisoner of Paul

@graph.rdfs:comment:
Given their joint mention by Paul, it seems likely that Junia was Andronicus' spouse, though this is not explicitly stated. Paul's description of Andronicus and Junia as "my kinsmen" is taken in the general sense (e.g. coming from the same region), rather than literally. 
Given they were Christians before Paul, their conversion must have been relatively early in the history of the church, and so it is quite likely they also visited Jerusalem (though this is nowhere stated). 
Much controversy rests on whether this description means they were well-known _to_ the apostles, or well-known _as_ apostles.
@graph.rdfs:label: Junia

@graph.rdfs:comment: The Kidron Brook/Valley is just outside the walls of Jerusalem
@graph.rdfs:label: Kidron

nt:description.@value: a man Jesus brought back to life

@graph.rdfs:comment: There's no evidence to suggest a connection between Lazarus of Bethany and the same-named subject of Jesus' parable.
@graph.rdfs:label: Lazarus

nt:description.@value: One of Jesus' twelve apostles

@graph.rdfs:comment: One of the Twelve, also known as Matthew.
@graph.rdfs:label: Levi

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Levi

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Levi

@graph.rdfs:comment: All Levites are Jewish by definition.
@graph.rdfs:label: Levite

@graph.rdfs:comment: Distinguished from Jews not by different beliefs, but by special roles related to observation of temple worship.
@graph.rdfs:label: Levites

@graph.nt:description: the grandmother of Timothy
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Her Christian belief is implied by Paul's commendation of her faith. Her daughter Eunice lived in Lystra, but her residence is unknown.
@graph.rdfs:label: Lois

@graph.nt:description: a companion of Paul's who sent greetings to the Roman church
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: This person may be the same as Lucius of Cyrene, but there's no clear evidence other than the name. His residence in Corinth follows from the inference that Paul resided there when he wrote the letter to the Roman church.  "kinsman" here probably means that that he is a Jew, rather than an actual relation, given the number of people so designated in Romans 16.
@graph.rdfs:label: Lucius

@graph.nt:description: a Christian leader in Antioch
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: This person may be the same as the Lucius in Rome, but there's no clear evidence other than the name.
@graph.rdfs:label: Lucius

nt:description.@value: a convert from Paul's preaching in Philippi

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Maath

@graph.rdfs:comment: Of the region of Macedonia (and therefore also Greek).
@graph.rdfs:label: Macedonian

nt:description.@value: an apocalyptic opponent of God's people

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Though in its original Old Testament context Magog  referred to a region, its New Testament usage seems to describe a group of people.
@graph.rdfs:label: Magog

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Mahalaleel

@graph.nt:description: a Christian leader at Antioch
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: The term translated "foster-brother" means Manaen and Herod Antipas were raised together, though not literally relatives.
@graph.rdfs:label: Manaen

nt:description.@value: the sister of Lazarus and Mary who annointed Jesus before his death
the mother of Jesus

@graph.rdfs:comment: See the note on Joseph for why Mary is childOf Heli. She is described by John as standing at the foot of Jesus' cross with two other Marys. Her relationship to John assumes he is the "beloved discipled" described in John's gospel.
@graph.rdfs:label: Mary

@graph.nt:description: A woman from whom seven demons had been exorcised
@graph.rdfs:comment: From Magdala, a town in Galilee not mentioned in the New Testament
@graph.rdfs:label: Mary Magdalene

nt:description.@value: a woman to whose house Peter came after his release from prison
a follower of Jesus who annointed him late in his ministry

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: There are other accounts of an unnamed woman annointing Jesus with oil, and various arguments about whether these were the same or different women.
@graph.rdfs:label: Mary

nt:description.@value: a woman to whom Paul sent greetings in his letter to the Romans

@graph.nt:description: A follower of Jesus who was present at the crucifixion
@graph.rdfs:comment: Comparing the Gospel accounts in John.19.25 and Mark.15.40, this Mary appears to be the same woman as the mother of James and Joseph/Joses, and therefore sister of Mary the mother of Jesus.
@graph.rdfs:label: Mary

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Mattatha

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Mattathias

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Mattathias

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Melchi

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Melchi

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not mentioned in the New Testament: of the people of Moab, a non-Jewish group.
@graph.rdfs:label: Moabite

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Naggai

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Nahor

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Nahum

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Paul addresses "the family/household of Narcissus", which may refer to slaves: so we have no evidence about the beliefs or other attributes of Narcissus himself, other than his residence in Rome.
@graph.rdfs:label: Narcissus

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:comment: This is not the prophet contemporary with King David, but David's son.
@graph.rdfs:label: Nathan

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Neri

@graph.rdfs:comment: Not referenced as a belief system in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Nicolatianism

nt:description.@value: the church in Laodicea met in her house

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: The Church in Laodicea met in her house. Some manuscript variants indicate a man rather than a woman.
@graph.rdfs:label: Nympha

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew and Luke's geneaologies
a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Part of the ancient empire of Persia, though under Roman domination in New Testmament times.

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.rdfs:comment: The Apostle Paul was known earlier as Saul: he was given the name Paul when he was converted.
@graph.rdfs:label: Paul

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Peleg

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.nt:description: One who worked hard in the Lord among the Roman Christians
@graph.rdfs:label: Persis

@graph.rdfs:comment: Pharaoh is actually a title rather than a personal name, but in the New Testament it refers to a single individual.
@graph.rdfs:label: Pharaoh

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Having a ReligiousBelief of Pharisee implies the belief of Jew as well.
@graph.rdfs:label: Pharisee

@graph.rdfs:comment: The beliefs of one of the main Jewish sects during the life of Jesus. In the New Testament the name of the sect is used, though not the belief system per se.
@graph.rdfs:label: Phariseeism

@graph.rdfs:comment:
His residence in Colossae is implied from his relationship to Archippus and Onesimus (Col.4.9; Col.4.17). He may have been been a native as well. 
Paul describes him as "our beloved fellow worker".
@graph.rdfs:label: Philemon

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:label: Philip

@graph.nt:description: King of the land east of the Jordan
@graph.rdfs:label: Philip

nt:description.@value: a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings
a Roman to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.nt:description: Deaconess of the Church of Cenchreae
@graph.rdfs:comment: Paul's commendation of Phoebe in Romans strongly suggests she delivered the letter
@graph.rdfs:label: Phoebe

nt:description.@value: a Christian who refused to help Paul during his Roman imprisonment

@graph.rdfs:comment: The circumstances behind his "turning away" from Paul are unknown. Likewise, Paul's description of him as being "is Asia" isn't specific enough to assign a place.
@graph.rdfs:label: Phygelus

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Prisca is the diminutive form of Priscilla. Brownrigg notes that Paul always uses this form.
rdfs:label: Prisca
Priscilla

nt:description.@value: one of Jacob's wives

@graph.rdfs:comment: Daughter of Laban and sister of Leah, who are not named in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Rachel

@graph.nt:description: An Old Testament example of faith who hid Joshua's spies
@graph.rdfs:label: Rahab

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: The only NT reference is a quotation from Jer 31:15: this presumably refers to Ramah near Bethel.
@graph.rdfs:label: Ramah

nt:description.@value: husband of Isaac

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Brother of Laban, who is not named in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Rebecca

@graph.nt:description: A king of Israel, and one of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His occupation as king comes from the Old Testament, 1Kgs.12-14
@graph.rdfs:label: Rehoboam

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Reu

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Rhesa

@graph.nt:description: a maid in the house of Mary, mother of John Mark
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: One might infer Rhoda was a Christian because of her mistress' faith, and her joy in seeing Peter after his release.
@graph.rdfs:label: Rhoda

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: There are no firm grounds for identifying this Rufus as the same person as the son of Simon of Cyrene mentioned in Mark 15 (though the tradition that Mark's Gospel was written in Rome makes this an intriguing possibility).

nt:description.@value: an ancestor of King David in Matthew's genealogy of Jesus

@graph.rdfs:comment: An Old Testament figure
@graph.rdfs:label: Ruth

@graph.rdfs:comment: The beliefs of one of the main Jewish sects during the life of Jesus. In the New Testament the name of the sect is used, though not the belief system per se.
@graph.rdfs:label: Sadduceanism

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Geodata assumes this is an earlier name for Jerusalem, though this is not certain.
@graph.rdfs:label: Salem

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew and Luke's geneaologies

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Luke's genealogy has Sala, a minor variant, but the relationships make clear it is the same person.
@graph.rdfs:label: Salmon

nt:description.@value: one of the woman who came to annoint Jesus' body after his crucifixion

@graph.rdfs:comment:
Matthew and Mark's accounts of the crucifixion together identify Salome as the mother of the sons of Zebedee. 
This is also the traditional name of the daughter of Herodias, whose dance before King Herod led to the beheading of John the Baptist. But this woman is not named in the New Testament.
@graph.rdfs:label: Salome

@graph.rdfs:comment: This may be overly precise positioning for a region
@graph.rdfs:label: geodata for Samaria

@graph.rdfs:comment: Samaria was both a province in Palestine and a city of the same name.
@graph.rdfs:label: Samaria

@graph.rdfs:comment: A Jewish sect centered around the city of Samaria: in New Testament times, there was great emnity between Samaritans and Jews.
@graph.rdfs:label: Samaritan

@graph.rdfs:comment: The Jewish supreme council
@graph.rdfs:label: Sanhedrin

nt:description.@value:
a member of the early church who misrepresented a gift and died as a 
    consequence
the wife of Abraham and an example of faith

@graph.rdfs:comment: An important Old Testament figure. Curiously enough, both Abraham and Sarah are described as having Terah as father, presumably by different mothers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Sarah

@graph.rdfs:comment: Herodotus describes the Scythians as a savage race of nomads, living generally north of the Black and Caspain Seas. Paul's single use of the term seems largely synonymous with them as a type of barbarians.
@graph.rdfs:label: Scythian

@graph.nt:description: a Thessalonian companion of Paul's
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: Luke describes him as "of the Thessalonians", which could mean either his residence or his origin.
@graph.rdfs:label: Secundus

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Semein

@graph.nt:description: procounsul of Cyprus and 'a man of intelligence'
@graph.rdfs:label: Sergius Paulus

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Serug

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Shealtiel

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: A subregion of Canaan.
@graph.rdfs:label: Shechem

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Shelah

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Shem

@graph.rdfs:comment: A pool outside the walls of Jerusalem.
@graph.rdfs:label: Siloam

@graph.nt:description: A leader in the church of Antioch
@graph.rdfs:label: Simeon

@graph.nt:description: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Luke's geneaology
@graph.rdfs:label: Simeon

@graph.nt:description: One of the twelve sons of Jacob, whose name is adopted for one of the Twelve Tribes of Israel.
@graph.rdfs:label: Simeon

@graph.nt:description: A righteous man present in the temple when Jesus was presented as a baby
@graph.rdfs:label: Simeon

@graph.nt:description: Simon was forced to carry Jesus' cross by the Romans who were taking him to be cruficied
@graph.rdfs:comment: Identified as a Jew because, though a foreigner, he was in Jerusalem at the time of Passover
@graph.rdfs:label: Simon

@graph.nt:description: one of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: The main definition for the Apostle Peter.
@graph.rdfs:label: Simon Peter

nt:description.@value: Simon Peter stayed at Simon the Tanner's house in Joppa

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:comment: Simon the Zealot was also known as Simon the Cananaean (but the term is one of political, not geographic, affiliation).
@graph.rdfs:label: Simon

nt:description.@value: King of Israel renowned for his wisdom
a companion of Paul's who sent greetings to the Roman church

@graph.rdfs:comment: "kinsman" here probably means that that he is a Jew, rather than an actual relation, given the number of people so designated in Romans 16. His residence in Corinth follows from the inference that Paul resided there when he wrote the letter to the Roman church.
@graph.rdfs:label: Sosipater

nt:description.@value: a Christian in Rome to whom Paul sent greetings

@graph.rdfs:comment: His residence in Corinth and visit to Ephesus follow from Paul's statement in 1Cor.16.17, and the assumption that Paul was in Ephesus when he wrote 1 Corinthians.
@graph.rdfs:label: Stephanas

nt:description.@value: a woman who contributed to Jesus' support

@graph.rdfs:comment: Jesus spoke here with a Samaritan woman about living water
@graph.rdfs:label: Sychar

nt:description.@value: a Philippian Christian who worked alongside Paul

@graph.rdfs:comment: Of the country of Syria.
@graph.rdfs:label: Syrian

@graph.rdfs:comment: Likely synonymous with Canaanite, and referring to those from the region of Syria and Phoenicia, and therefore a subgroup of Greek Gentiles.
@graph.rdfs:label: Syrophoenician

nt:description.@value: a Christian in Joppa known for her charity

@graph.rdfs:comment: The Aramaic name Tabitha corresponds to the Greek form Dorcas. She probably also knew Simon the Tanner.
rdfs:label: Tabitha
Dorcas

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
the scribe of Paul's letter to the Roman church

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His residence in Corinth follows from the inference that Paul resided there when he wrote the letter to the Roman church.
@graph.rdfs:label: Tertius

@graph.nt:description: an orator enlisted by Ananias the high priest to speak against Paul to Felix
@graph.rdfs:comment: Speaking on behalf of the Sanhedrin does not imply Tertullus was Jewish: more likely (but not certain), he was a Roman, hired for his familiarity with Roman law. But the account describes him as traveling from Jerusalem with the others.
@graph.rdfs:label: Tertullus

@graph.nt:description: One of Jesus' twelve apostles
@graph.rdfs:label: Thomas

@graph.rdfs:comment: Tiberias was built by Herod Antipas, the tetrarch of Galilee, as his capital.
@graph.rdfs:label: Tiberias

@graph.nt:description: Roman Emperor at the time of Jesus' ministry
@graph.rdfs:comment: Caesar is used as a name for several different individuals in the New Testament. This is the Caesar referred to by Jesus.
@graph.rdfs:label: Tiberius Caesar

@graph.rdfs:comment: Timothy's residence in Corinth follows from the close of Paul's letter to the Romans, assumed to have been written from Corinth.
@graph.rdfs:label: Timothy

@graph.nt:description: a "worker in the Lord" in Rome
@graph.rdfs:label: Tryphaena

@graph.nt:description: a "worker in the Lord" in Rome
@graph.rdfs:label: Tryphosa

nt:description.@value: a Christian in Rome to whom Paul sent greetings
One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.rdfs:comment: From OT sources, Uriah was a Hittite and a soldier in David's army (therefore having both collaboratesWith and hasEnemy relationships with David).
@graph.rdfs:label: Uriah

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com: His occupation as King comes from Old Testament sources.
@graph.rdfs:label: Uzziah

@graph.rdfs:comment: Jesus recounts the story of Elijah being sent to a widow of Zarephath as an example of God blessing those outside the nation of Israel.
@graph.rdfs:label: Zarephath

nt:description.@value: One of the ancestors of Jesus mentioned in Matthew's geneaology
